title: Bonds reign supreme, equities struggle on recession, Brexit fears
text: Global bond yields flirted with record lows while stocks struggled to recover on Thursday, as global recession worries from intensifying U.S.-China frictions and the specter of a no-deal Brexit drove investors to safer harbors.

title: Oil prices hold gains after US inventory draw down
text: Oil prices clung to gains on Thursday after official data confirmed a big drop in U.S. crude inventories, helping ease concerns about weakening demand, but worries about wider economic growth held prices in check.

title: Stocks to rise as rate cuts beat back trade worries for now: Reuters poll
text: World stocks will keep rising over the coming year, according to the latest Reuters polls of strategists, but wild gyrations are likely in the lift from expected central bank policy easing and drag from developments in the U.S.-China trade war.

title: Peter Navarro: Yield curve is inverting due to bullish circumstances
text: White House trade adviser Peter Navarro discusses the inverted yield curve, the USMCA trade agreement and the U.S.-China trade war.

title: Fed's Daly says she's in a 'watch and see' mode on rates
text: San Francisco Federal Reserve President Mary Daly on Thursday said she is in a "watch and see" mode as she assesses the need for another U.S. interest-rate cut, but said she believes acting early is better than waiting too long.

title: Asia stocks slip as investors watch US Treasury yields
text: Stocks in Asia slipped Thursday morning as investors continue to watch the yield curve in U.S. Treasurys, which inverted further overnight.

title: Natixis Speaks Effect of Volatility on International ETF
text:
During a call to ETF Trends, Natixis portfolio manager Alexander Nary provided some insight regarding recent market volatility and how its International Minimum Volatility ETF (MVIN) has been faring. Nary made it clear, some substantial changes to the ETF were made to take into account the recent volatility. There’s been a little higher turnover because of it. [...]
The post Natixis Speaks Effect of Volatility on International ETF appeared first on ETF Trends.

title: Did Bitcoin Definitively Break Down With Wednesday's Drop?
text: Today's drop could be the expected move out of a trading range in Bitcoin. Is it the start of a longer downward move or a way for bulls to shake out weak hands?

title: U.S. does not intend to intervene in currency markets for now, Mnuchin tells Bloomberg
text: U.S. Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said on Wednesday the United States does not intend to intervene in currency markets for now, Bloomberg News reported.

title: The countdown to recession has begun, but one strategist says markets will rally first
text: Tony Dwyer Canaccord Genuity, says markets will rally before the coming recession hits.

title: Retailers howl as U.S. trade agency locks in 15% tariffs on Sept.
text: The Trump administration on Wednesday made official its extra 5% tariff on $300 billion in Chinese imports and set collection dates of Sept. 1 and Dec.

title: Stocks Are Sitting in a 'Death Zone,' MKM's O'Hara Says
text: In this edition of "Smart Charts," MKM Partners Chief Market Technician JC O'Hara examines the performance of U.S. stocks and money market funds with Bloomberg's Taylor Riggs on "Bloomberg Markets: What'd You Miss?"

title: This chart could be a screaming sell sign that bodes ill for market
text: Looking at a 'megaphone top,' or what could be a screaming sell sign. With CNBC's Melissa Lee and the Futures Now traders, Tim Seymour, Brian Kelly, Steve Grasso and Guy Adami.

title: Consumer healthy and not watching yield curve or trade war: Kniffen
text: Jan Kniffen, CEO of J. Rogers Kniffen WWE and CNBC Contributor, discusses the latest retail earnings and the state of the U.S. consumer.

title: Bonds look 'pretty attractive' as a cautious play for next 3 to 6 months, UBS' Jason Draho says
text: Jason Draho of UBS Global Wealth Management discusses the bond market on CNBC's "Closing Bell.

title: Bonds Send Bullish Message to Stock Investors
text: Bonds continued their unrelenting rally on Wednesday, and although there’s no whiff of the panic that swept through markets late last week, the surge nonetheless drove benchmark yields down to unprecedented levels.

title: Box beats estimates on revenue, earnings per share
text: CNBC's Josh Lipton reports on Box earnings.

title: Stocks rise as recession, trade worries ebb; sterling tumbles
text: A gauge of equities worldwide rose on Wednesday as data showing strong demand for oil helped subdue recession jitters, while sterling tumbled as Britain's prime minister moved to suspend parliament before the country's planned departure from the European Union.

title: A recession isn't imminent as we see more good economic data, says CIO
text: Herb Morgan, CIO of Efficient Market Advisors, talks about his expectations for the market in September on "Closing Bell.

title: Dow Jones Today: Glossing Over Some Things
text: Adding to those concerns was a separate poll of would-be homebuyers that indicates more than a third are expecting a recession to arrive in 2020. Reading the tea leaves here, it would be reasonable to assume that, like him or not, President Trump is shrewd enough to realize that the trade war with China is seen as crimping the economy and he cannot carry that baggage into 2020 and hope to be reelected.

title: Nasdaq 100 Shows Stocks Are in Corrective Process, Macro Risk's Kolovos Says
text: In this edition of "Charting Futures," Macro Risk Advisors' John Kolovos examines the Nasdaq 100 and commodities prices with Bloomberg's Taylor Riggs on "Bloomberg Markets: The Close.

title: Bitcoin drops below $10,000 in sudden afternoon swoon
text: Bitcoin fell about $530, or 5%, in a 40-minute span after being mostly flat for the day, continuing a volatile year for the cryptocurrency.

title: U.S. 30-year bond yields hit record low, curve inversion grows
text: U.S. Treasury debt yields fell on Wednesday, with 30-year yields setting all-time lows, as fears about a recession and trade tensions between China and the United States stoked unrelenting demand for low-risk government debt.

title: Oil prices gain nearly 2% after drop in U.S. crude inventories
text: Oil prices rose nearly 2% on Wednesday after a larger-than-expected decline in U.S. crude stockpiles helped ease worries about weakening oil demand caused by the trade war between Washington and Beijing.

title: US Stocks Edge Higher Wednesday
text: U.S. stocks were in the green on Wednesday, with energy stocks pulling the market up.

title: U.S. Pipelines to 'Significantly' Increase Oil Production, Yergin Says
text: Dan Yergin, former vice chairman of IHS Markit, discusses the relationship between the oil markets and U.S. economy. He speaks with Bloomberg's David Westin on "Balance of Power."

title: Financials, energy lead Wall Street bounce
text: U.S. stocks advanced on Wednesday, as gains in financial and energy shares helped equities recover from initial declines,  but investors remained cautious about the potential for another flare-up in U.S.-China trade tensions.

title: Fed's Barkin says watching growth, monitoring impact of last rate cut
text: Richmond Federal Reserve President Thomas Barkin on Wednesday said he was closely watching developments around the outlook for economic growth but had yet to make up his mind on whether the economy needs another interest rate cut.

title: The Fed's efforts to stay out of politics just got a lot tougher this week
text: The Fed and its long-held independence crucial to its decision-making are facing a test perhaps like never before.

title: U.K. Goes Prorogue, What Does That Mean For Markets?
text: Boris Johnson proroguing Parliament is an extreme move, one for an extreme situation. The media has suggested the financial markets were shocked but the British pound dropped just 1% and the stock market traded on as if nothing had happened.

title: Ron Insana: It ain't different this time for the inverted yield curve
text: Don't ignore the inversion curve. It's not different this time.

title: Yield curve inversion shows current cycle likely to end mid-2020: CIO
text: Paul Christopher, Wells Fargo Investment Institute, and Hugh Johnson, Hugh Johson Advisors, join 'The Exchange' to discuss the market recovery,

title: Financials help Wall Street bounce back
text: U.S. stocks recovered from early losses on Wednesday, helped by financial stocks, although investors were guarded as worries about a recession loomed and trade tensions between the United States and China dragged on.

title: While Wall St. Talks of Recession, Bond Investors Make a Killing
text: You should have bought bonds. They’re doing great.

title: US recession could come sooner than most expect: Fmr. GS exec
text: Jim O'Neill, former Goldman Sachs Asset Management chairman and former Commercial Secretary to the Treasury in Britain, calls into 'Fast Money Halftime Report' to discuss the state of the global economy and what could be The Fed's next move.

title: RockCreek Group Founder Afsaneh Beschloss Sees Investment Opportunities in China
text: RockCreek Group Founder Afsaneh Beschloss talks about investment opportunities in China.

title: US equities remain good investment strategy: Fmr. JPM chief strategist
text: Adam Parker, Trivariate Capital Management, and Brenda Vingiello, Sand Hill Global Advisors CIO, join 'Fast Money Halftime Report' to discuss where investors should be putting their money amid rising recession fears.

title: Wall Street rebounds as financial shares gain
text: Gains in financial shares helped U.S. stocks reverse early losses on Wednesday, although investors were guarded amid worries about a recession and trade tensions between the United States and China.

title: Fed Needs to Cut by 75 Basis Points, Says Tom Lee
text: Tom Lee of Fundstrat Advisors talks about the Fed and President Trump. He appears on "Bloomberg Markets."

title: FBI agents raid home of United Auto Workers union President Gary Jones, Dow Jones reports
text: The raid comes as the union and Big Three Detroit automakers are negotiating new contracts for 158,000 UAW workers.

title: UBS' Vinay Pande: We don't expect a recession because the US consumer is doing well
text: Ian Lyngen, BMO Capital Markets head of U.S. rates strategy, and Vinay Pande, UBS Global Wealth Management head of trading strategies, join "Squawk Alley" to discuss the markets and fears of a recession.

title: Muni Bond Demand Withstands Record-Low 30-Year Yield: Invesco
text: Aug.28 -- Stephanie Larosiliere, senior municipal strategist at Invesco, examines the impact of a record-low 30-Year yield on the municipal bond market.

title: Don't Ignore The Yield Curve; Sell Stocks And Buy Bonds
text: I have mentioned in prior Forbes columns that an inverted yield curve is a pronounced negative for stocks, and, in fact, the previous two 3-30 inversions (ending in December 2000 and April 2007) presaged major market meltdowns.

title: UBS Wealth Management Turns Bearish on Equities
text: Mark Haefele, global chief investment officer at UBS Wealth Management, explains the factors behind the firm's move to underweight on stocks.

title: What Investors Need to Know About Peloton Going Public, Okta and the Market
text: Here's what investors need to know about Peloton, Okta and the market.

title: Gold bars with faked logo slipped into global markets, JPMorgan vaults: report
text: Gold bars stamped with faked logos of major refineries have been circulated into the global market and landed in the vaults of JPMorgan Chase & Co. – part of a plot to launder smuggled or illegal specimens of the precious metal, according to a report.

title: 'I think it's the beginning of a new bull market in gold,' says portfolio manager
text: Van Eck Portfolio Manager Joe Foster discusses why investors are  looking to gold to hedge market volatility.

title: Jobless claims show chance of a recession is low, says economist
text: Lindsey Bell, market investment strategist, and Tom Porcelli, RBC Capital Markets chief U.S. economist, join "Squawk on the Street" to discuss the global markets and chance of a recession.

title: The rich pull back spending as recession fears grow
text: There seems to be a tale of two economies which, for years favored the top, is now flipping.

title: Why China Holds a Trade War Edge Over U.S.
text: Art Hogan, chief market strategist at National Securities, examines a Bloomberg Economics study of 700,000 data points that shows China with a trade war edge over the U.S. He speaks on "Bloomberg Daybreak: Americas."
